question.text: How much amount of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math> should be added to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>600</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of water <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.00</mn><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced></math> to decrease the freezing point of water to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn><msup><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>? ________. (The freezing point depression constant for water <math><mo>=</mo><mn>2 </mn><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K </mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> )

solution.text:
∆Tf=0.2°C
∆Tf= ikfm
0.2=2×2×ω58.5×1000600
ω=0.2×58.5×6001000×4=1.2×58.540=01.76 g

Freezing point depression is the phenomena that describes why adding a solute to a solvent results in the lowering of the freezing point of the solvent.
